cards.name: 7 Colored Fish
cards.reviewText: 1800 is a great ATK for its time and for a LVL 4 monster.

cards.name: Ancient Brain
cards.reviewText: Ugh here we go again with the trash

cards.name: Ancient Elf
cards.reviewText: An elf with mid stats

cards.name: Ancient Lizard Warrior
cards.reviewText: A lizard with mid stats

cards.name: Armored Lizard
cards.reviewText: A lizard with slightly better but still mid stats

cards.name: Armored Zombie
cards.reviewText: Mid again, and an introduction to the 0 DEF trope with zombies.

cards.name: Baby Dragon
cards.reviewText: Iconic card used by Yugi in the anime to fuse Thousand Dragon

cards.name: Barrel Dragon
cards.reviewText: The probability of getting at least two heads when flipping coins is 50%. So not bad actually. But the stats for a monster that needs 2 tributes are very disappointing.

cards.name: Battle Steer
cards.reviewText: Any normal monster that needs a tribute and has < 2000 ATK immediately gets a 1, just letting yall know now

cards.name: Bickuribox
cards.reviewText: I like the art, but another just 'not worth it' fusion

cards.name: Big Eye
cards.reviewText: Cute lil effect where the eye means u can see ur deck's top cards. I like the creativity, but it's a FLIP effect so you have to wait a turn and it's not worth it tbh.

cards.name: Black Skull Dragon
cards.reviewText: Now we're talking. A fusion of 2 iconic cards and a 3200 ATK beatstick. Still not super practical in competitive play though even at the time.

cards.name: Blackland Fire Dragon
cards.reviewText: Mid stats for a dragon. It even has a weakness in its card description.

cards.name: Bladefly
cards.reviewText: The first of a set of early cards that had ATK increase for one attribute and ATK decrease for another. This actually saw use in early Harpie decks, and also EARTH was a pretty common attribute so this gnat definitely had use.

cards.name: Blast Juggler
cards.reviewText: Not too bad- the < 1000 ATK really limits it though. At the time there wasn't much monster removal (only Dark Hole, Fissure, etc which were limited) so this actually did see use.

cards.name: Block Attack
cards.reviewText: It's a simple, positive effect. A lot of monsters had really low DEF (compared to their ATK) and this could be a way to do that. Still way too slow for competitive play though even for the time.

cards.name: Blue-Winged Crown
cards.reviewText: Decent stats for a LVL 4. Not much else to say.

cards.name: Bottom Dweller
cards.reviewText: Yeah you really are buddy.

cards.name: Cannon Soldier
cards.reviewText: An iconic monster that is a pioneer of the burn OTK strategies and absolutely still holds relevance today. It's one of the cards that didn't have a limit on its burn effect (praying no errata is made), which Konami REALLY tries to limit with modern cards. The possibilities are endless- you can pair Cannon Soldier with token generators (Scapegoat) or Frogs that constantly regenerate monsters. Easy 10/10.

cards.name: Castle of Dark Illusions
cards.reviewText: A Fiend ATK/DEF support card with those weird early Yugioh stats. Unfortunately, it didn't see much play because it is simply too slow (needs FLIP, only +200 each turn).

cards.name: Catapult Turtle
cards.reviewText: Used by Yugi in the anime. Half the ATK of a tributed monster isn't bad, but REALLY held back by the need for a tribute and the once per turn limit (unlike Cannon Soldier). I think it wasn't once per turn originally but now that the Once per turn limit is added it's completely unusable.

cards.name: Change of Heart
cards.reviewText: Another iconic spell. Taking control of a monster for free was, and still is, one of the strongest effects in the game. It was banned for years and years and is now limited and still widely used as a staple.

cards.name: Cocoon of Evolution
cards.reviewText: Used as a shield for Petit Moth so it can survive longer. But the whole Petit Moth to Great Moth thing was so absolutely unplayable (even back then) this still gets a 1.

cards.name: Crass Clown
cards.reviewText: A key part of the infamous 'Clown Control' decks (along with Dream Clown) that aimed to get field advantage combined with stall cards, due the reusability of his effect. Never really saw much competitve play but still made a cool GOAT format deck.

cards.name: Crawling Dragon
cards.reviewText: Crawl ur way off my screen.

cards.name: Cyber Saurus
cards.reviewText: T Rex with a minigun is American asf lol. The card is godawful but I'll give it some extra credit just for the art/concept.

cards.name: Dark Elf
cards.reviewText: One of the first 'restricted LVL 4 monsters with >= 2000 ATK'. Could be useful to immediately get over a powerful LVL4 monster but just not really worth it in the long run.

cards.name: Deepsea Shark
cards.reviewText: How r yall today?

cards.name: Destroyer Golem
cards.reviewText: Mid statted LVL4 pack filler once again.

cards.name: Disk Magician
cards.reviewText: Mid statted LVL4 pack filler once again

cards.name: Doma The Angel of Silence
cards.reviewText: Hard card art but idc I'm following my 'shitty LVL 5+ normal monsters get a 1' rule

cards.name: Dragon Piper
cards.reviewText: WAYYYY too situational, I guess it could be used as a side deck card??? Obviously would see no use today and probably didn't back then either.

cards.name: Dream Clown
cards.reviewText: The main part of the Clown Control archetype, and much better than the bouncing effect of Crass Clown. Combined with stall cards like Swords of Revealing Light, Messenger of Peace, Gravity Bind, etc, Dream Clown can slowly give field advantage one turn at a time. Clown Control overall is just realistically too slow (even for the time), but it still has a cult following today.

cards.name: Electric Lizard
cards.reviewText: Scary ass card art and effect is too slow. Get off my screen.

cards.name: Elegant Egotist
cards.reviewText: Now we're moving- this is the heart and soul of the Harpie archetype. At the time, VERY few cards allowed free Deck summons, so it gave Harpies a unique swarm potential.

cards.name: Empress Judge
cards.reviewText: Off my screen please. Baddie though.

cards.name: Fake Trap
cards.reviewText: Cute effect, but the reality is this is literally useless unless your opponent tries to destroy your traps, and it also has to be set, taking up a whole S/T zone until the condition is fulfilled. Cheeks.

cards.name: Feral Imp
cards.reviewText: Used in the anime but mid again

cards.name: Flame Cerebrus
cards.reviewText: At least it's > 2000 ATK.

cards.name: Garnecia Elefantis
cards.reviewText: Underwhelming stats for a monster that need 2 tributes. Sorry.

cards.name: Gate Guardian
cards.reviewText: Unbelievably iconic card and in the anime. But this is one of the most difficult to summon monsters in Yugioh history, making it unplayable (except in Duel Links where there's a skill that makes it easier). 3 Level 7 monsters needing to be on the field is just way too long. It also just had no protection after all that. But it's a collector's favorite.

cards.name: Gazelle the King of Mythical Beasts
cards.reviewText: Was frequently used by Yugi the anime and is a fusion material for Chimera the Flying Mythical Beast (along with Berfomet). Other than that, not much else to say.

cards.name: Germ Infection
cards.reviewText: Drops ATK by 300 points each turn. While technically positive, still just painfully slow and never saw competitive play.

cards.name: Giga-Tech Wolf
cards.reviewText: HARD ass card art but bad stats.

cards.name: Giltia the D. Knight
cards.reviewText: Nice Link ripoff lol. Get off my screen.

cards.name: Great Moth
cards.reviewText: Just way too slow and unusable. Petit Moth + Cocoon of Evolution needs to survive for 4 turns, AND great moth needs to be in your hand. Stats aren't even that good lol.

cards.name: Ground Attacker Bugroth
cards.reviewText: Mid, but they made more bugroths which have cool art.

cards.name: Guardian of the Labyrinth
cards.reviewText: Ass

cards.name: Harpie Lady
cards.reviewText: Heart of Mai Valentine's deck and core of the Harpie archetype. Mid stats. Fun fact: only three copies of any “Harpie Lady” (including alternate forms like Harpie Lady Sisters, Cyber Harpie Lady) could be in your Deck, which forced players to choose which versions to run.

cards.name: Harpie Lady Sisters
cards.reviewText: Seems like a boss monster but is just too clunky and mid stats-wise to be used competitively (can be said about the whole Harpie archetype). You could only Special Summon it with Elegant Egotist while controlling a Harpie Lady, and was a complete dead draw otherwise.

cards.name: Heavy Storm
cards.reviewText: Now we're cooking again- one of the most format-defining spells in Yugioh history, still seeing heavy (no pun intended) play to this day. The ability to completely wipe out opponent's backrow is still absurdly powerful and was often enough to win the game. It's bounced between LIMITED and BANNED for years and years now.

cards.name: Hibikime
cards.reviewText: I really should just leave these mid normal monsters as 1 to save time

cards.name: Horn of Heaven
cards.reviewText: The first of the summon negation cards, used by Kaiba in the anime. Back in the day field presence won duels so a tribute was a tough decision. Today this might be less of a cost, but there's just better cards like Solemn Judgment and Solemn Warning. Never really saw competitive play.

cards.name: Hoshiningen
cards.reviewText: The LIGHT variant of Bladefly. Obviously will see use in LIGHT-centered archetypes. But still just too slow and the stats are just bad.

cards.name: Hunter Spider
cards.reviewText: Off.

cards.name: Hyosube
cards.reviewText: My.

cards.name: Illusionist Faceless Mage
cards.reviewText: Screen.

cards.name: Insect Soldiers of the Sky
cards.reviewText: Decent I guess (it becomes 2000 ATK when it attacks WIND) but still too situational. And just cheeks when it battles a non WIND.

cards.name: Jellyfish
cards.reviewText: That is a jellyfish! Any other cards with generic names of species? Where is 'Ant'? 'Monkey'?

cards.name: Jinzo #7
cards.reviewText: One of the first 'direct attacker' cards in the game. It could be used with stall cards like Swords of Revealing Light, and then add on equip spells that boost ATK, but that's just too slow and it still just never saw competitive play.

cards.name: Jirai Gumo
cards.reviewText: A semi-infamous card. Amazing ATK for a LVL4- but a steep cost if u lost the coin flip. Back in the day though, field presence was king, and it was worth it to beat over other cards even at the risk of LP halving. Jirai Gumo actually did see competitive experimentation in aggressive decks back in the day, but obviously became obselete over time.

cards.name: Kaminari Attack
cards.reviewText: Wtf even is this lol

cards.name: Kazejin
cards.reviewText: One of the three iconic guardian pieces for Gate Guardian. Its reduce ATK to 0 ability was neat but too clunky. 2 Tributes for this mid-statted monster was just too much.

cards.name: Killer Needle
cards.reviewText: Beedrill ripoff lol. Also fuck it for normal monsters unless they have ABOVE AVERAGE stats (e.g. 7 colored fish, la jinn) I'm giving them a default 1.

cards.name: King of Yamimakai
cards.reviewText: Yeesh.

cards.name: Kojikocy
cards.reviewText: Following the rule made at Killer Needle. Life is so much easier this way.

cards.name: Kuriboh
cards.reviewText: One of the most iconic monsters in Yugioh and a close pal of Yugi as a 'protector card', but never really good enough to see real life play. It was legitimately the first 'hand trap' which would become ESSENTIAL in Modern Yugioh, even if Kuriboh itself was trash. Over time, it received tons of spin-offs (Winged Kuriboh, Sphere Kuriboh, etc.) and even its own archetype support as a fan-favorite.

cards.name: Labyrinth Tank
cards.reviewText: Decent stats actually but just not worth it.

cards.name: Lady of Faith
cards.reviewText: Zero faith in this bitch

cards.name: Larvae Moth
cards.reviewText: LOL what even is the point if ur gonna do all that setup just to bring this little fuck out

cards.name: Launcher Spider
cards.reviewText: Terrible stats but hard card art.

cards.name: Lava Battleguard
cards.reviewText: Tristan’s signature monster in the anime, but just completely unplayable. Its effect gave it a 500 ATK boost if Swamp Battleguard was on the field, but that synergy required running two bad cards just to get to a still-mediocre 2050 ATK monster.

cards.name: Leghul
cards.reviewText: Same review as Jinzo #7, but this is actually worse lol.

cards.name: Leogun
cards.reviewText: Lion

cards.name: Little Chimera
cards.reviewText: Same review as Hoshingen and Bladefly.

cards.name: Magic Jammer
cards.reviewText: One of the first widely played Counter Traps. At a time when power spells like Raigeki, Dark Hole, and Change of Heart could decide games instantly, having a way to stop them was extremely valuable. But still discarding a card meant this was a -1 in card advantage. Saw solid competitive play back then but nearly zero today.

cards.name: Magician of Faith
cards.reviewText: Yes. A cornerstone of GOAT format, this magician is one of the most powerful FLIP monsters of early Yugioh. Letting you reuse spells like Raigeki, Dark Hole, etc. was just insane. As the card pool expanded and spells became stronger, Magician of Faith eventually became too powerful and was banned for years. Unfortunately it's been power crept today, but still an iconic staple of early Yugioh.

cards.name: Mask of Darkness
cards.reviewText: The Trap counterpart of Magician of Faith. The problem was that traps, even good ones like Mirror Force, Torrential Tribute, etc., are INHERENTLY slower than spells and less game-breaking when used multiple times. So it never came close to seeing the play that Magician of Faith did.

cards.name: Masked Sorcerer
cards.reviewText: GREAT effect (Drawing is one of the most powerful things you can do in the game) but unfortunately not backed by good enough stats.

cards.name: Mega Thunderball
cards.reviewText: Headache is starting to rise

cards.name: Milus Radiant
cards.reviewText: Wtf is this lol? Doggo with piercings? That's crazy.

cards.name: Morinphen
cards.reviewText: Gross.

cards.name: Muka Muka
cards.reviewText: Interesting effect but on a full hand of 5 cards that's just 2100 atk and obviously this lowers when cards leave the hand. Keeping a large hand size was impractical without stalling, so this never saw play.

cards.name: Mushroom Man #2
cards.reviewText: One of the stranger cards that kind of had like a chicken game like effect of control switching back and forth. But also just too insignificant of a card to do anything.

cards.name: Musician King
cards.reviewText: Lady + Lady = man?

cards.name: Mystic Horseman
cards.reviewText: Generic centaur

cards.name: Mystic Lamp
cards.reviewText: Same review as Jinzo #7 and Leghul

cards.name: Niwatori
cards.reviewText: This is me after Thanksgiving lol

cards.name: Ocubeam
cards.reviewText: Creepy as hell but shite

cards.name: Ooguchi
cards.reviewText: Same review as Jinzo #7, Leghul, Mystic Lamp

cards.name: Pale Beast
cards.reviewText: Creepy af but mid

cards.name: Paralyzing Potion
cards.reviewText: Not too bad actually for stopping an opponents boss monster. But obviously there are better cards than this.

cards.name: Petit Moth
cards.reviewText: Not worth the whole thing for Great Moth or even Perfectly Ultimate Great Moth.

cards.name: Prevent Rat
cards.reviewText: Decent DEF but I don't care these still get 1s.

cards.name: Princess of Tsurugi
cards.reviewText: One of the earliest burn monsters along with Cannon Soldier and Catapult Turtle. The FLIP effect could sometimes chunk off 1500-2000 LP in one shot which was definitely significant. But relying on that backrow being fully set was the issue and it was inconsistent because of that. Definitely did see play in burn decks though.

cards.name: Protector of the Throne
cards.reviewText: Ok

cards.name: Pumpking the King of Ghosts
cards.reviewText: Cool theme but too clunky and slow. Also needed a TRIBUTE wtf lol.

cards.name: Punished Eagle
cards.reviewText: How is it punished?

cards.name: Queen's Double
cards.reviewText: Same review as the other ones.

cards.name: Rabid Horseman
cards.reviewText: Cool art I guess.

cards.name: Rainbow Flower
cards.reviewText: ZZZZZ

cards.name: Ring of Magnetism
cards.reviewText: Interesting concept that forced players to attack it, but just not worth really doing since opponent can just not attack and wait for a fissure/smashing ground or something.

cards.name: Roaring Ocean Snake
cards.reviewText: Leviathan is cool but terrible stats.

cards.name: Robbin' Goblin
cards.reviewText: Now we're talking. In Yugioh card advantage always has been king, and Robbin Goblin allows you to potentially completely clear their hand. That said, the card is a bit setup dependent and only works if you're already winning, linmiting its potential.

cards.name: Rock Ogre Grotto #1
cards.reviewText: Ok

cards.name: Ryu-Kishin Powered
cards.reviewText: I'm about to throw up bro

cards.name: Saggi the Dark Clown
cards.reviewText: I deadass ran out of shit to say

cards.name: Sanga of the Thunder
cards.reviewText: One of the three iconic guardian pieces for Gate Guardian. Its reduce ATK to 0 ability was neat but too clunky. 2 Tributes for this mid-statted monster was just too much.

cards.name: Sangan
cards.reviewText: one of the most iconic searchers in Yugioh history. Searching for ANY < 1500 ATK monster is just ridiculous on an easy-to-trigger effect. In competitive play, Sangan was a staple for years. It fetched Exodia pieces and gave combo decks like Chaos and Goat Control reliable access to key monsters. It eventually got so format-defining it was BANNED for many years. Unfortunately this boy got nerfed with an errate that lets us use it once per turn and cannot activate the card during the same turn.

cards.name: Seven Tools of the Bandit
cards.reviewText: Like Magic Jammer, one of the most important early Counter Traps. It provided a reliable way to negate backrow WITHOUT sacrificing card advantage. In its prime, it was a clutch way to shut down the scariest trap threats of the early game

cards.name: Shadow Ghoul
cards.reviewText: Interesting but just not good enough unless your in the late late game and the grave is absolutely loaded with monsters.

cards.name: Share the Pain
cards.reviewText: Very interesting effect that is also unique; forcing opponent to tribute a monster. It meant this could also clear monsters that were unaffected by effects, because this was a COST. Never really saw competitive play though.

cards.name: Shield & Sword
cards.reviewText: Swapping ATK/DEF is interesting and could be used for 3000 DEF monsters (Labyrinth wall) but too slow/clunky for real play.

cards.name: Skull Knight
cards.reviewText: Decent stats for non-effect fusions.

cards.name: Solemn Judgment
cards.reviewText: Behold the most feared counter trap in Yugioh history. Paying half your life points sounds costly, but it was an ALL-PURPOSE negation. This gave it a long-lasting place in the meta. Over the years, its usage grew to the point it spent several formats BANNED. In modern play, the key is to protect the winning position- LP doesn't really matter if you keep that.

cards.name: Soul Release
cards.reviewText: Banishing cards were actually ahead of their time- this didn't really matter in early Yugioh, but now actually sees some play in the side deck for disrupting graveyard-based decks.

cards.name: Star Boy
cards.reviewText: Shoutout the Weeknd

cards.name: Steel Scorpion
cards.reviewText: Yeah any of these destroyed after X turns cards is getting an auto 1

cards.name: Stim-Pack
cards.reviewText: Decent enough in the short term I guess. Just use a better equip spell tho.

cards.name: Suijin
cards.reviewText: One of the three iconic guardian pieces for Gate Guardian. Its reduce ATK to 0 ability was neat but too clunky. 2 Tributes for this mid-statted monster was just too much

cards.name: Summoned Skull
cards.reviewText: One of Yugi's iconic boss monsters and a staple in the early meta. An unrestricted 2500 ATK as a one tribute monster is actually maximal, and was the go-to high-power beatstick for years. It also had synergy with Fiend support cards and even got its own spinoffs.

cards.name: Swamp Battleguard
cards.reviewText: Like its Lava brother, complete dogshit.

cards.name: Sword of Deep-Seated
cards.reviewText: The forcing to be back on top of the deck is ridiculous and can actually harm you so this gets a 1.

cards.name: Tainted Wisdom
cards.reviewText: Shuffling my deck does nothing positive for me. Unless there's a super niche effect liek Parasite Paracide.

cards.name: The Bistro Butcher
cards.reviewText: Absolutely the fuck not lol

cards.name: The Cheerful Coffin
cards.reviewText: I guess this could be useful for decks that want monsters in the Graveyard, but there's just better alternatives (Foolish Burial). It did see play though.

cards.name: The Immortal of Thunder
cards.reviewText: Very solid LP gain but even without the drawback LP gain just isn't good. There's better ways for mass LP gain than the risk of net -2000.

cards.name: The Little Swordsman of Aile
cards.reviewText: Not remotely close to enough ATK, and its TEMPORARY lol. Fuck off my screen.

cards.name: The Unhappy Maiden
cards.reviewText: One of the earliest stall monsters. This could buy one turn of survival basically. Even back then though this didn't see much play, and stall decks just used straightforward high-DEF monsters like Giant Soldier of Stone.

cards.name: Thousand Dragon
cards.reviewText: Famously used by Joey WHeeler in the anime, but extremely underwhelming as a Fusion. Unsurprisingly, never saw competitive play.

cards.name: Thunder Dragon
cards.reviewText: One of those monsters that surprisingly aged well over time. Terrible stats but great effect to generate hand advantage, used for thinning out deck for Exodia or just generic hand fodder for discard costs. Later on it got its own archetype which actually did see competitive play.

cards.name: Time Wizard
cards.reviewText: An iconic gambling monster used by Joey. Massive game-changing potential but had extra damage effect if u lost the coin flip. Never really saw serious competitive play because alternatives like Raigeki/Dark Hole were just better.

cards.name: Tongyo
cards.reviewText: Freaky ahh fish

cards.name: Tremendous Fire
cards.reviewText: Decent i guess, if u need to finish off that last 1000 LP and u had enough LP of your own.

cards.name: Trent
cards.reviewText: Trent Williams

cards.name: Tribute to the Doomed
cards.reviewText: Gave some flexibility in monster removal by letting you choose the monster to be destroyed, but that discard cost could actually be beneficial (Dark World, Fabled). Saw some competitive use but not much.

cards.name: Twin-Headed Thunder Dragon
cards.reviewText: Actually very solid for a fusion monster and could easily get the 2 pieces with Thunder Dragon's effect. I like it.

cards.name: Water Omotics
cards.reviewText: Uncensored titty is crazy. Where's her nipples?

cards.name: White Magical Hat
cards.reviewText: Like Masked Sorceror, GREAT effect but bad backing stats.

cards.name: Winged Dragon, Guardian of the Fortress #1
cards.reviewText: Such a long name for midness

cards.name: Witch of the Black Forest
cards.reviewText: Behold, in its original un-nerfed un-erratad form, the most powerful searcher in Yugioh history. 1500 DEF allowed FAR more search range than even Sangan. Like Sangan it was banned for many many years until it got sadly erratad.

cards.name: Witch's Apprentice
cards.reviewText: Same as others

cards.name: Yado Karu
cards.reviewText: The fuck is even the point of doing that? In any order I desire? This card is just weird lol. Bye Mr. Krabs.
